title: Jeremiah Chapter 25 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Jeremiah chapter 25 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Jeremiah Chapter 25 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Jeremiah Chapter 25.

questions.question: In which year of Jehoiakim king of Judah did the word come to Jeremiah according to Jeremiah 25:1?
questions.correctAnswer: Fourth year
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:1 states that the word came to Jeremiah in the fourth year of Jehoiakim the son of Josiah king of Judah.

questions.question: Whom did Jeremiah speak to according to Jeremiah 25:2?
options: All the people of Judah and inhabitants of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: All the people of Judah and inhabitants of Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:2 says Jeremiah spoke unto all the people of Judah and to all the inhabitants of Jerusalem.

questions.question: How long had the word of the LORD come unto Jeremiah by the time of Jeremiah 25:3?
options: From the thirteenth year of Josiah to the twenty-third year
questions.correctAnswer: From the thirteenth year of Josiah to the twenty-third year
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:3 states that the word of the LORD came from the thirteenth year of Josiah until the twenty-third year.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 25:6, what were the people warned not to do?
options: Go after other gods to serve and worship them
questions.correctAnswer: Go after other gods to serve and worship them
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:6 warns the people not to go after other gods to serve and worship them.

questions.question: Who is described as the LORD's servant in Jeremiah 25:9?
questions.correctAnswer: Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:9 calls Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon the LORD's servant.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 25:11, how many years shall the nations serve the king of Babylon?
questions.correctAnswer: Seventy years
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:11 states that the nations shall serve the king of Babylon seventy years.

questions.question: What will happen after the seventy years are accomplished according to Jeremiah 25:12?
options: The LORD will punish the king of Babylon and his nation
The people of Judah will be freed
Nebuchadrezzar will be made king of Israel
The land will be restored immediately
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will punish the king of Babylon and his nation
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:12 says when seventy years are accomplished, the LORD will punish the king of Babylon and his nation.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 25:15, what did the LORD command Jeremiah to take?
questions.correctAnswer: The wine cup of fury
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:15 instructs Jeremiah to take the wine cup of fury at the LORD's hand.

questions.question: Who is included among the nations Jeremiah was commanded to make drink the wine cup according to Jeremiah 25:18?
options: Jerusalem and the cities of Judah
Only the kings of the north
questions.correctAnswer: Jerusalem and the cities of Judah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:18 mentions Jerusalem, the cities of Judah, and their kings as among those to drink the cup.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 25:19 mentions Pharaoh king of Egypt among those to drink the cup of God's fury.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:19 lists Pharaoh king of Egypt, his servants, princes, and people among those to drink the cup.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 25:28 says if nations refuse to drink the cup at Jeremiah's hand, they will not be forced to drink it.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:28 states if they refuse to take the cup, they shall certainly drink it anyway.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 25:33 states the slain of the LORD will be buried with honor.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:33 says the slain will not be lamented, gathered, nor buried; they will be dung upon the ground.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Jeremiah 25:7: 'Yet ye have not hearkened unto me, saith the LORD; that ye might provoke me to anger with the works of your ______ to your own hurt.'
questions.correctAnswer: hands
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:7 uses the phrase 'works of your hands' to describe what provokes God's anger.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Jeremiah 25:31: 'A noise shall come even to the ends of the earth; for the LORD hath a controversy with the nations, he will plead with all ______; he will give them that are wicked to the sword, saith the LORD.'
questions.correctAnswer: flesh
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:31 says the LORD will plead with all flesh.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 25:38, why is the land desolate?
options: Because of the fierceness of the oppressor and the LORD's fierce anger
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the fierceness of the oppressor and the LORD's fierce anger
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:38 explains the land is desolate due to the fierceness of the oppressor and the LORD's fierce anger.

medium.title: Jeremiah Chapter 25 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Jeremiah Chapter 25 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with obedience to God's commands. Based on Jeremiah 25, what biblical truth would you share about the consequences of not hearkening to God?
options: God will send judgment through the king of Babylon and desolation will come upon the land.
God will immediately forgive and forget all sins without consequence.
God will remove His prophets from speaking to the people.
God will protect the disobedient from any harm.
questions.correctAnswer: God will send judgment through the king of Babylon and desolation will come upon the land.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:7-9 explain that because the people have not hearkened to God's words, He will send Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon to bring desolation. Jeremiah 25:11 also notes the land will be made desolate.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 25 teach us about perseverance in spiritual discipline despite hearing God's word repeatedly?
options: Keep rising early and speaking God's word even if people do not listen.
Stop preaching if people refuse to listen.
Only preach to those who are willing to hear.
Focus on worldly matters instead of spiritual discipline.
questions.correctAnswer: Keep rising early and speaking God's word even if people do not listen.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:3 shows Jeremiah rising early and speaking God's word continually despite the people's refusal to listen, modeling perseverance in spiritual discipline.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to follow other gods. What biblical wisdom from Jeremiah 25 could you share about faithfulness and trust in God?
options: Do not go after other gods to serve and worship them, lest you provoke God to anger.
It is acceptable to worship other gods alongside the LORD.
God does not care which gods you serve.
Following other gods will bring you blessings.
questions.correctAnswer: Do not go after other gods to serve and worship them, lest you provoke God to anger.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:6 instructs not to follow other gods or worship them, warning that such actions provoke God to anger and bring harm.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 25 emphasize the importance of repentance and turning from evil deeds for family and community wellbeing?
options: Turn everyone from evil ways to dwell safely in the land given by God to your fathers forever.
Ignore the evil ways since God will protect you regardless.
Only leaders need to repent, not the people.
Repentance is unnecessary if you are righteous.
questions.correctAnswer: Turn everyone from evil ways to dwell safely in the land given by God to your fathers forever.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:5 highlights the call to turn from evil to live in the land God provided, implying collective responsibility for repentance and community wellbeing.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 25 teach about God's justice in dealing with nations according to their deeds?
options: God will recompense nations according to their deeds and works.
God will show favoritism and exempt some nations.
All nations are forgiven regardless of their actions.
Nations are left to their own justice without God's involvement.
questions.correctAnswer: God will recompense nations according to their deeds and works.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:14 states that God will recompense nations based on their deeds and the works of their own hands, emphasizing divine justice.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged by trials and wonders about God's sovereignty. Based on Jeremiah 25, what truth about God's control over history would encourage them?
options: God uses kings like Nebuchadrezzar as His servants to carry out His purposes.
God has no control over earthly rulers.
History is random and lacks divine purpose.
God punishes only Israel, not other nations.
questions.correctAnswer: God uses kings like Nebuchadrezzar as His servants to carry out His purposes.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:9 refers to Nebuchadrezzar as God's servant used to bring judgment, showing God's sovereign control over history and rulers.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 25 instruct believers about trust and contentment in the face of prolonged hardship?
options: The land and nations will serve Babylon for seventy years, after which God will punish Babylon and restore justice.
Hardship will last forever without hope.
Believers should abandon faith during trials.
God will rescue immediately without delay.
questions.correctAnswer: The land and nations will serve Babylon for seventy years, after which God will punish Babylon and restore justice.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:11-12 teaches that though Babylon will dominate for seventy years, God will later punish Babylon, encouraging trust and hope during hardship.

questions.question: True or False: According to Jeremiah 25, God sent prophets repeatedly to call the people to repentance, but they did not listen.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:4 states that God sent all His servants the prophets repeatedly, yet the people did not hearken or incline their ears to hear.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 25 teaches that God's judgment will be limited only to Judah and Jerusalem without affecting other nations.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:26 and verses 18-26 list many nations and kings who will drink the cup of God's fury, showing judgment is not limited to Judah.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah was instructed to take the wine cup of _____ at God's hand and cause all the nations to drink it.
questions.correctAnswer: fury
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:15 directs Jeremiah to take the wine cup of fury at God's hand to make the nations drink, symbolizing God's judgment.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 25 teach about honesty and integrity in spiritual witness when confronting nations with their sin?
options: Speak plainly about the coming judgment and call them to drink the cup of God's wrath.
Avoid mentioning their sin to keep peace.
Only speak of God's love without judgment.
Blame other nations instead of confronting them.
questions.correctAnswer: Speak plainly about the coming judgment and call them to drink the cup of God's wrath.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:27-28 shows Jeremiah faithfully declaring God's message to the nations about drinking the cup of wrath, exemplifying honest spiritual witness.

questions.question: A believer faces temptation to compromise. How does Jeremiah 25 counsel believers about consequences of provoking God with their deeds?
options: Provoking God with evil works leads to harm and punishment.
Consequences are only temporary and insignificant.
questions.correctAnswer: Provoking God with evil works leads to harm and punishment.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:7 warns that provoking God with the works of hands leads to hurt and judgment.

questions.question: What lesson about humility and contentment can be drawn from Jeremiah 25 regarding the destruction of the shepherds and principal of the flock?
options: Prideful leaders will fall like pleasant vessels and have no escape during judgment.
Leaders will always be safe regardless of their actions.
Contentment is found in wealth and power alone.
Ignoring God's warnings will protect leaders.
questions.correctAnswer: Prideful leaders will fall like pleasant vessels and have no escape during judgment.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:34-35 describes how shepherds and leaders will fall and have no way to flee, teaching humility and the consequences of pride.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 25 encourage believers to have a work ethic and integrity in daily life through God's justice?
options: God will recompense people according to their deeds and works of their hands.
God rewards only those born into privilege.
Integrity has no impact on God's judgment.
God's justice is random and unpredictable.
questions.correctAnswer: God will recompense people according to their deeds and works of their hands.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:14 teaches that God rewards or punishes according to the deeds and works of individuals, encouraging honest labor and integrity.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 25 illustrate the importance of prayer and intercession when facing national or communal trials?
options: Prophets like Jeremiah intercede by proclaiming God's word and warnings to the people.
Prayer is unnecessary when judgment is certain.
Only kings should pray for the nation.
Trials indicate God has abandoned His people.
questions.correctAnswer: Prophets like Jeremiah intercede by proclaiming God's word and warnings to the people.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25 shows Jeremiah faithfully delivering God's message, acting as an intercessor calling for repentance and warning of judgment.

hard.title: Jeremiah Chapter 25 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Jeremiah Chapter 25.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 25:9, Nebuchadrezzar is referred to as what in relation to the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: My servant
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:9 calls Nebuchadrezzar 'my servant,' indicating divine sovereignty over the Babylonian king despite his role as an instrument of judgment.

questions.question: What is the duration of the nations serving the king of Babylon as prophesied in Jeremiah 25:11?
questions.correctAnswer: Seventy years
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:11 clearly states that these nations shall serve the king of Babylon for seventy years, a timeframe linked to Israel's exile.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 25:12, what will happen to the king of Babylon and the land of the Chaldeans after seventy years?
options: They will be punished for their iniquity
They will become a great empire
questions.correctAnswer: They will be punished for their iniquity
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:12 states that after seventy years, God will punish the king of Babylon and the land of the Chaldeans for their sins, indicating a cycle of judgment.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah 25:6 warns against going after other ____ to serve and worship them.
questions.correctAnswer: gods
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:6 specifically commands not to follow other gods, emphasizing monotheistic worship.

questions.question: What literary device is used in Jeremiah 25:10 to describe the removal of joy from the land?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:10 uses parallelism by listing contrasting joyful sounds like mirth, gladness, bridegroom, and bride to emphasize the completeness of desolation.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 25:14 indicates that many nations and great kings will serve themselves by taking advantage of Babylon’s power.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:14 notes that many nations and great kings will use Babylon’s dominance for their own benefit, indicating political dynamics in the ancient Near East.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 25:15, what symbolic item does the LORD instruct Jeremiah to take and cause the nations to drink?
questions.correctAnswer: The wine cup of fury
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:15 uses the imagery of a 'wine cup of fury' as a symbol of God's judgment to be poured out on the nations.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 25:27, what will happen to those who drink the cup of the LORD’s wrath?
options: They will be drunken, spew, fall, and rise no more
They will be healed and restored
questions.correctAnswer: They will be drunken, spew, fall, and rise no more
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:27 vividly describes the effects of God's judgment as overwhelming and final for the nations.

questions.question: Jeremiah 25:30 uses the image of the LORD roaring from on high. This is an example of which literary device?
questions.correctAnswer: Personification
questions.explanation: The LORD is given human attributes of roaring and shouting in Jeremiah 25:30, illustrating divine power and judgment through personification.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 25:33 say will happen to the slain of the LORD on that day?
options: They shall not be lamented, gathered, nor buried; they shall be dung upon the ground
They shall be honored with great ceremonies
They shall be buried with kings
questions.correctAnswer: They shall not be lamented, gathered, nor buried; they shall be dung upon the ground
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:33 describes a horrific fate for the slain, emphasizing total desolation and divine judgment.

questions.question: The phrase 'the king of Sheshach' in Jeremiah 25:26 is a cryptic reference to which kingdom?
questions.correctAnswer: Babylon
questions.explanation: Scholars recognize 'Sheshach' as a cryptogram or cipher for Babylon, linking this to the theme of Babylonian judgment.

questions.question: Jeremiah 25:34 commands shepherds and principals of the flock to do what in response to their slaughter?
options: Howl, cry, and wallow in ashes
questions.correctAnswer: Howl, cry, and wallow in ashes
questions.explanation: The verse uses vivid imagery of mourning and lamentation, reflecting the severity of judgment on leaders and people.

questions.question: Which nations are explicitly mentioned in Jeremiah 25 among those who must drink the cup of God's fury?
options: Pharaoh king of Egypt, Edom, Moab, all kings of Tyrus and Zidon
questions.correctAnswer: Pharaoh king of Egypt, Edom, Moab, all kings of Tyrus and Zidon
questions.explanation: Verses 19-22 enumerate these specific nations, showing the wide scope of divine judgment across neighboring powers.

questions.question: Jeremiah 25:4 emphasizes the LORD sending what to the people of Judah repeatedly?
questions.correctAnswer: His servants the prophets
questions.explanation: This verse highlights God's persistent attempts to call Judah to repentance through prophets.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 25:29 indicates that the city called by God's name will be punished justly and not escape judgment.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:29 confirms that Jerusalem, the city named for the LORD, will not be exempt from punishment.

theological.title: Jeremiah Chapter 25 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Jeremiah Chapter 25 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 25, what is the primary reason God sends Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon against Judah and the surrounding nations?
options: Because the people did not listen to God's words
questions.correctAnswer: Because the people did not listen to God's words
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:8-9 explains that God will send Nebuchadrezzar because the people have not heard His words. This reflects God's justice in response to human disobedience, consistent with passages like Deuteronomy 28:15-68, Isaiah 1:20, Ezekiel 14:21, and Romans 1:18-28.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah say has been the response of the people of Judah to the prophets sent by the LORD from the thirteenth year of Josiah until the twenty-third year?
options: They have not hearkened nor inclined their ear to hear
They have worshiped the LORD only
They have sought the prophets eagerly
questions.correctAnswer: They have not hearkened nor inclined their ear to hear
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:3-4 reveals that despite many prophetic messages, the people did not listen or turn from their evil ways. This aligns with themes of human rebellion found in Isaiah 6:9-10, Ezekiel 12:2, Hebrews 3:7-11, and Romans 10:16.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 25, what symbolic action does the LORD instruct Jeremiah to perform involving a cup?
options: Take the wine cup of fury and make all the nations drink it
Pour out a cup of blessing on Jerusalem
Fill a cup with water and offer it to the people
Break a cup to symbolize destruction
questions.correctAnswer: Take the wine cup of fury and make all the nations drink it
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:15-17 commands Jeremiah to take the cup of God's fury and cause all nations to drink it as a symbol of impending judgment. This imagery is echoed in Revelation 14:10, Isaiah 51:17, Psalm 75:8, and Habakkuk 2:16.

questions.question: What is the duration of the nations' servitude to the king of Babylon as prophesied in Jeremiah 25?
questions.correctAnswer: Seventy years
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:11 states that the nations will serve the king of Babylon for seventy years. This period is significant in biblical history and prophecy, also referenced in Daniel 9:2, 2 Chronicles 36:21, Ezra 1:1-4, and Jeremiah 29:10.

questions.question: Which voices and sounds does God say He will remove from the land as part of the judgment in Jeremiah 25?
options: The voice of mirth, gladness, the bridegroom, the bride, millstones, and candlelight
The voice of the prophet, the priest, the king, and the people
The sound of the trumpet, the harp, the flute, and the drum
The cries of children, the elders, the merchants, and the farmers
questions.correctAnswer: The voice of mirth, gladness, the bridegroom, the bride, millstones, and candlelight
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:10 lists these specific sounds as being taken away, symbolizing the cessation of joy and normal life due to God's judgment. Similar themes are in Amos 5:16-17, Isaiah 24:7-8, Lamentations 2:11, and Ezekiel 7:19.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 25, what will happen to the slain of the LORD on the day of judgment?
options: They will not be lamented, gathered, or buried, but become dung upon the ground
They will be glorified and honored
They will be buried with great ceremony
questions.correctAnswer: They will not be lamented, gathered, or buried, but become dung upon the ground
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:33 describes a grim judgment where the slain are left unburied, emphasizing the severity of God's wrath. This motif appears in Ezekiel 39:11-12, Isaiah 26:14, Revelation 6:9-11, and Psalm 79:3-5.

questions.question: Which nations and peoples are included among those who must drink the cup of God's fury according to Jeremiah 25?
options: Jerusalem, Judah, Egypt, Philistines, Edom, Moab, Ammon, Tyre, Sidon, Arabia, Elam, Medes, and others
Only the northern tribes of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Jerusalem, Judah, Egypt, Philistines, Edom, Moab, Ammon, Tyre, Sidon, Arabia, Elam, Medes, and others
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:18-26 lists a broad coalition of nations subject to judgment, showing God's sovereignty over all nations. This is consistent with passages like Isaiah 13, Ezekiel 25-32, and Revelation 16.

questions.question: What does the LORD say will happen if the nations refuse to take the cup of fury from Jeremiah's hand to drink?
options: They shall certainly drink it anyway
They will be spared from judgment
They will be given a second chance
questions.correctAnswer: They shall certainly drink it anyway
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:28 teaches that refusal will not prevent judgment; God's decrees are inevitable. This doctrinal truth is supported by Hebrews 10:31, Romans 2:5, Ezekiel 14:23, and Revelation 14:10.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 25 describe the LORD's voice from His holy habitation when He judges the inhabitants of the earth?
options: He shall mightily roar and give a shout as those who tread grapes
He shall speak softly and gently
He shall sing a song of peace
He shall whisper secrets to the prophets
questions.correctAnswer: He shall mightily roar and give a shout as those who tread grapes
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:30 depicts God's voice as powerful and overwhelming, symbolizing divine judgment. Parallel imagery appears in Joel 3:16, Amos 1:2, Nahum 1:2, and Revelation 19:6.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 25 reveal about God's justice towards the king of Babylon after the seventy years of servitude?
options: God will punish the king of Babylon for their iniquity
God will exalt the king of Babylon forever
God will forget the king of Babylon
God will bless the king of Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: God will punish the king of Babylon for their iniquity
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:12 indicates that after the period of judgment on Judah, God will hold Babylon accountable for its own sins. This principle of divine justice is echoed in Isaiah 47:6-8, Daniel 5:26-31, Habakkuk 2:6-8, and Revelation 18.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 25 say about the peaceable habitations in the land during the judgment?
options: They are cut down because of the fierce anger of the LORD
They will be protected and preserved
questions.correctAnswer: They are cut down because of the fierce anger of the LORD
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:37 describes destruction of peaceful dwellings as a consequence of God's fierce anger. This reflects God's righteous judgment seen in Isaiah 5:5-7, Ezekiel 7:23, Lamentations 2:6, and Nahum 1:2.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 25 characterize the LORD's relationship to His land and people during the time of desolation?
options: He has forsaken His covert like a lion
He is always present and protective
He is indifferent to their plight
questions.correctAnswer: He has forsaken His covert like a lion
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:38 uses the metaphor of a lion forsaking its shelter to illustrate God's withdrawal due to judgment. Similar themes of God's temporary forsaking appear in Psalm 22:1, Hosea 9:17, Lamentations 5:20, and Ezekiel 10:18-19.

questions.question: What is the response Jeremiah is instructed to proclaim to the nations after they drink the cup of God's fury?
options: "Drink ye, and be drunken, and spue, and fall, and rise no more"
"Rejoice and be glad in the LORD"
"Repent and be saved from the wrath"
"Sing praises to the Most High God"
questions.correctAnswer: "Drink ye, and be drunken, and spue, and fall, and rise no more"
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:27 commands Jeremiah to declare this vivid judgment language to the nations, emphasizing the irreversible consequences of sin. This is consistent with Revelation 14:10, Isaiah 51:17, and Psalm 75:8.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 25 say about the nations and great kings in relation to the families of the north and Nebuchadrezzar?
options: Many nations and great kings shall serve themselves of them and be recompensed according to their deeds
They will be united in peace forever
They will be destroyed without cause
They will rise up against God
questions.correctAnswer: Many nations and great kings shall serve themselves of them and be recompensed according to their deeds
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:14 describes a complex divine judgment where nations serve the instrument of God's wrath but are also judged fairly. This fits with Romans 13:1-7, Isaiah 10, and Daniel 4.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 25 reveal about God's controversy with the nations and His judgment on all flesh?
options: The LORD has a controversy with the nations and will give the wicked to the sword
God is impartial and will not judge the nations
God will pardon all nations without judgment
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD has a controversy with the nations and will give the wicked to the sword
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 25:31 states God's universal justice that involves a plea against all flesh and judgment on the wicked. This is consistent with Psalm 9:7-8, Romans 2:5-16, Revelation 19:11-21, and Ecclesiastes 12:14.
